{{color box|#007C41}} {{color box|#FFDB05}} |nickname = The [[Alberta Golden Bears|Golden Bears]] (men), The [[Alberta Pandas|Pandas]] (women) |mascot = GUBA (men), Patches (women) |athletics = [[U Sports]] – [[Canada West Universities Athletic Association|Canada West]] |website = {{URL|https://www.ualberta.ca/}} |logo = University of Alberta Logo.svg }} The '''University of Alberta''' (also known as '''U of A''' and '''UAlberta''') is a [[Public university|public]] research university located in [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], Canada. It was founded in 1908 by [[Alexander Cameron Rutherford]],"A Gentleman of Strathcona – [[Alexander Cameron Rutherford]]", Douglas R. Babcock, 1989, The [[University of Calgary]] Press, 2500 University Drive NW, [[Calgary]], Alberta, Canada, {{ISBN|0-919813-65-8}} the first premier of Alberta, and [[Henry Marshall Tory]],"[[Henry Marshall Tory]], A Biography", originally published 1954, current edition January 1992, E.A. Corbett, Toronto: Ryerson Press, {{ISBN|0-88864-250-4}} its first president. Its enabling legislation is the ''Post-secondary Learning Act.''{{cite web|url=http://www.qp.alberta.ca/574.cfm?page=p19p5.cfm&leg_type=Acts&isbncln=9780779737932|title=Post-secondary Learning Act|date=2006-12-28|publisher=Qp.alberta.ca|accessdate=2012-06-20}} The university comprises four campuses in Edmonton, the Augustana Campus in Camrose, and a staff centre in downtown Calgary. The original north campus consists of 150 buildings covering 50 city blocks on the south rim of the [[North Saskatchewan River valley parks system|North Saskatchewan River valley]], directly across from [[downtown Edmonton]]. 39,000 students from Canada and 150 other countries participate in 400 programs in 18 faculties. The University of Alberta is a major economic driver in Alberta. The university's impact on the Alberta economy is an estimated $12.3 billion annually, or five per cent of the province's gross domestic product.{{cite web |url=http://www.news.ualberta.ca/article.aspx?id=2CA43617BB3C4D1FAAE2A50D5911279F |title=U of A has $12.3-billion impact on Alberta economy |date=October 2, 2012 |accessdate=2012-10-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121009182632/http://www.news.ualberta.ca/article.aspx?id=2CA43617BB3C4D1FAAE2A50D5911279F |archive-date=October 9, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} The university has been recognized by the [[Academic Ranking of World Universities]], the [[QS World University Rankings]] and the [[Times Higher Education World University Rankings]] as one of the top five universities in Canada and one of the top 100 universities worldwide. According to the 2014 QS World University Rankings, the top Faculty Area at the University of Alberta is Arts and Humanities (ranked 89th in the world), and the top-ranked Subject is English Language and Literature (22nd in the world).{{cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/world-university-rankings/2014 |title=QS World University Rankings |publisher=QS Quacquarelli Symonds Limited |accessdate=2014-09-15}} The University of Alberta is also a leading institution for the study of Ukraine and is home to the [[Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.ualberta.ca/canadian-institute-of-ukrainian-studies/about/mandate|title=Mandate - Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies|website=www.ualberta.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-01-19}} The University of Alberta has graduated more than 260,000 alumni, including Governor General [[Roland Michener]]; Prime Minister [[Joe Clark]]; Chief Justice of Canada [[Beverley McLachlin]]; Alberta premiers [[Peter Lougheed]], [[Dave Hancock]], [[Jim Prentice]] and [[Rachel Notley]]; Edmonton Mayor [[Don Iveson]] and Nobel laureate [[Richard E. Taylor]]. The university is a member of the [[Alberta Rural Development Network]], the Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education and the Sustainability Tracking, Assessment & Rating System. ==History== [[File:Convocation Hall University of Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 02.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Old Arts Building, University of Alberta campus, designed by [[Percy Erskine Nobbs]] & [[Frank Darling (architect)|Frank Darling]] 1909–10.]] [[File:Tory Building University of Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 02.jpg|thumb|upright|Henry Marshall Tory Building at the University of Alberta]] [[File:Rutherford House University of Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 03.jpg|thumb|left|Rutherford House, on the northeast corner of the University of Alberta campus.]] [[File:University of Alberta Biology Building Pano.jpg|thumb|left|Biological Sciences Building at the University of Alberta]] [[File:Corbett Hall University Of Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 08A.jpg|thumb|Corbett Hall, University of Alberta campus.]] The University of Alberta, a single, public provincial university, was chartered in 1906 in [[Edmonton, Alberta]] with the University Act{{cite web |title= University Act, 1910|url= http://www.ualbertacentennial.ca/history/founding/university_act.html|publisher= University of Alberta|accessdate=October 9, 2012}} in the first session of the new [[Legislative Assembly of Alberta|Legislative Assembly]], with [[Premier (Canada)|Premier]] [[Alexander C. Rutherford]] as its sponsor. The university was modelled on the American state university, with an emphasis on extension work and applied research.{{cite web |title= University|url= http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0008242|publisher= [[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]|accessdate=October 9, 2012}} The governance was modelled on Ontario's University of Toronto Act of 1906: a bicameral system consisting of a senate (faculty) responsible for academic policy, and a board of governors (citizens) controlling financial policy and having formal authority in all other matters. The president, appointed by the board, was to provide a link between the two bodies and perform institutional leadership. Heated wrangling took place between the cities of [[Calgary]] and Edmonton over the location of the provincial capital and of the university. It was stated that the capital would be north of the North Saskatchewan River and that the university would be in a city south of it. The city of Edmonton became the capital and the then-separate city of [[Strathcona, Alberta|Strathcona]] on the south bank of the river, where Premier Alexander Rutherford lived, was granted the university. When the two cities were [[Amalgamation (politics)|amalgamated]] in 1912, Edmonton became both the political and academic capital. With [[Henry Marshall Tory]] as its first president, the University of Alberta started operation in 1908. Forty-five students attended classes in English, mathematics and modern languages, on the top floor of the Queen Alexandra Elementary School in Strathcona, while the first campus building, Athabasca Hall, was under construction."All True Things: A History of the University of Alberta, 1908–2008", Rod Macleod, The University of Alberta Press, 2008, {{ISBN|978-0-88864-444-2}} In a letter to [[Alexander Cameron Rutherford]] in early 1906, while he was in the process of setting up [[University of British Columbia|McGill University College]] in [[Vancouver]], Tory wrote, ''"If you take any steps in the direction of a working University and wish to avoid the mistakes of the past, mistakes which have fearfully handicapped other institutions, you should start on a teaching basis."''Tory to Rutherford, March 6, 1906. University of Alberta Archives (UAA), Rutherford Fonds, 2/3/6-8 Under Tory's guidance, the early years were marked by recruitment of professors and construction of the first campus buildings.{{cite web|title=University of Alberta Centenary - History|url=http://www.ualbertacentennial.ca/history/index.html|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=31 October 2012}} [[Percy Erskine Nobbs]] & [[Frank Darling (architect)|Frank Darling]] designed the master plan for the University of Alberta in 1909–10. Nobbs designed the Arts Building (1914–15), laboratories and Power House (1914). With Cecil S. Burgess, Nobbs designed the Provincial College of Medicine (1920–21).{{cite web|url=http://dictionaryofarchitectsincanada.org/architects/view/1452 |title=Percy Erskine Nobbs |publisher=Dictionaryofarchitectsincanada.org |accessdate=2012-06-20}} Architect Herbert Alton Magoon designed several buildings on campus, including St. Stephen's Methodist College (1910) and the residence for professor Rupert C. Lodge (1913).{{cite web|url=http://dictionaryofarchitectsincanada.org/architects/view/1460 |title=Herbert Alton Magoon (architect) |publisher=Dictionaryofarchitectsincanada.org |accessdate=2012-06-20}} The University of Alberta awarded its first degrees in 1912, the same year it established the Department of Extension. The Faculty of Medicine was established the following year,{{cite web |title= History of Medical Education in Canada|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com |publisher= [[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]|accessdate=October 20, 2009}} and the Faculty of Agriculture began in 1915. But along with these early milestones came the First World War and the global influenza pandemic of 1918, whose toll on the university resulted in a two-month suspension of classes in the fall of 1918. Despite these setbacks, the university continued to grow. By 1920, it had six faculties (Arts and Sciences, Applied Science, Agriculture, Medicine, Dentistry, and Law) and two schools (Pharmacy and Accountancy). It awarded a range of degrees: Bachelor of Arts (BA), Bachelor of Science (BSc), [[Bachelor of Science in Agriculture]] (BSA), [[Bachelor of Laws]] (LLB), [[Bachelor of Pharmacy]] (PhmB), [[Bachelor of Divinity]] (BD), [[Master of Arts]] (MA), [[Master of Science]] (MSc), and [[Doctor of Laws]] (LLD). There were 851 male students and 251 female students, and 171 academic staff, including 14 women.Dominion Bureau of Statistics, ''Canada Year Book 1921'', Ottawa, 1922 The Breton Soil Plots were established at the faculty of agriculture from 1929 – present to provide agricultural research on fertilization, usage, crop rotations and farming practices on Gray-Luvisolic soils (Gray-Wooded), which cover many regions in western Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.museevirtuel-virtualmuseum.ca/GetMuseumProfile.do?lang=en&chinCode=guaeva|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130628051947/http://www.museevirtuel-virtualmuseum.ca/GetMuseumProfile.do?lang=en&chinCode=guaeva|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-06-28|title=Breton Soil Plots}} The University of Alberta spearheaded an extraordinary rate of volunteerism in the Province of [[Alberta]] to the [[First World War]], especially from its medical faculty. Experience gained was used by returning [[veterans]] to rapidly mature the young [[Faculty of Medicine]].{{cite journal |title=Calgary, Edmonton and the University of Alberta: the extraordinary medical mobilization by Canada's newest province |journal= Can J Surg |year=2017 |pages=296–299 |volume=60 |issue= 5 |doi=10.1503/cjs.012117 |pmc=5608576 |pmid=28930035 | last1 = Da Cambra | first1 = MP | last2 = McAlister | first2 = VC}} The War Memorial Committee commissioned a War Memorial Pipe Organ to be erected by the [[Casavant Frères]] in U of A Convocation Hall in 1925 in memory of 80 University of Alberta comrades who gave up their lives during the Great War.{{cite web|url=https://www.ualberta.ca/ALUMNI/history/traditions/47octorgan.htm|title=Memorial Organ|accessdate=July 3, 2015}} In the early part of the 20th century, professional education expanded beyond the traditional fields of theology, law and medicine. Graduate training based on the German-inspired American model of specialized course work and the completion of a research thesis was introduced. In 1929, the university established a College of Education. This period of growth was to be short-lived, though, as the Great Depression and the Second World War curtailed enrolment and expansion until 1945. The university also gained new public powers. In 1928, the university's senate was granted the power to oversee and appoint half of the [[Alberta Eugenics Board]], charged with recommending individuals for sterilization.{{cite journal |last=Puplampu |first=Korbla |authorlink= |date=Summer 2008|volume=54|issue=2|journal=The Alberta Journal of Educational Research |title=Knowledge, Power, and Social Policy: John M. MacEachran and Alberta’s 1928 Sexual Sterilization Act|pages=129–146}} Spurred by postwar growth in the student population and the discovery of oil in Leduc in 1947, the University of Alberta underwent expansion through the 1950s that continued through the 1960s as the baby-boom generation swelled the enrolment ranks. These two decades also saw expansion of campus buildings, including new buildings for the faculties of physical education and education, and the Cameron Library. The [[University of Alberta Press]], concentrating on western Canadian history, general science and ecology, was founded in 1969.{{cite web |title= University Presses|url= http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=A1ARTA0008267|publisher= [[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]|accessdate=9 October 2012}} The policy of university education initiated in the 1960s responded to population pressure and the belief that higher education was a key to social justice and economic productivity for individuals and for society. In addition, the single-university policy in the West was changed as existing colleges of the provincial universities gained autonomy as universities. On September 19, 1960, the university opened a new 130-hectare campus in Calgary.{{cite book |title='Fitzhenry and Whiteside Book of Canadian Facts and Dates' |last=Pound |first=Richard W. |publisher=Fitzhenry and Whiteside |year=2005}} By 1966, the [[University of Calgary]] had been established as an autonomous institution. From the mid-1970s to the late 1980s, the university enjoyed sustained growth. In 1970, the Collège Saint-Jean began offering French-language instruction in arts, science and education. In 1984, the School of Native Studies was established. Buildings that had been started in the 1960s, such as Biological Sciences and the Central Academic Building, were completed in the early 1970s. Extensive renovations restored the venerable Arts Building, as well as the Athabasca and Pembina halls. New buildings completed in the early 1980s included the Business Building and the first phase of the Walter C. Mackenzie Health Sciences Centre. Another new building, the distinctive Universiade Pavilion (nicknamed the "Butterdome"), was completed as part of the university's preparations to host the World University Games in 1983, the first time the event was held in North America. The 1990s were a time of financial constraint as the Alberta government made budgetary cutbacks. but they were also a time in which the university benefited from philanthropic support. The $11-million Timms Centre for the Arts, which began construction in 1993, was made possible by a large donation from its namesake, Albert Timms. In 1998, Gladys Young's $3.5-million donation to the university undergraduate scholarship fund in memory of Roland Young, who graduated from the U of A in 1928, was the largest private donation for undergraduate scholarships in the university's history.{{cite web|title=Cobalt king remembers U of A with $3.5 million|url=http://www.folio.ualberta.ca/36/13/front.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130101075021/http://www.folio.ualberta.ca/36/13/front.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=1 January 2013|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=31 October 2012}} The early 2000s brought substantial funding increases. High energy prices drove Alberta's energy boom resulting in multibillion-dollar government surpluses{{cite web| year = 2005| url = http://www.gov.ab.ca/acn/200511/1907299D61F81-DEC8-EA80-06936D6F35D8786C.html| title = Record energy revenues boost province's surplus| publisher = Government of Alberta| accessdate = 7 November 2012}} and the subsequent creation of a $4.5 billion provincial post-secondary educational endowment.{{cite web| year = 2005| url = http://www.advancededucation.gov.ab.ca/news/2005/March/nr-Bill1.asp| title = Bill 1 to secure Albertans' access to the future| publisher = Government of Alberta| accessdate = 7 November 2012| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110516011437/http://www.advancededucation.gov.ab.ca/news/2005/March/nr-Bill1.asp| archive-date = May 16, 2011| dead-url = yes| df = mdy-all}} In 2005, the university hired [[Indira Samarasekera]] as its 12th president, embarking on an ambitious plan to establish itself as one of the world's top public research universities. These plans were hampered by the [[2008 economic downturn]], and by late March 2008, the university's endowment had shrunk by more than $100 million, almost 14 per cent of its value.{{cite news|title= U of A watches millions vanish|first= Keith|last= Gerein|url= http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=e4bf1774-0fbc-40d6-93c5-e4d674c05de5&p=1|archive-url= https://archive.is/20130118230115/http://www.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=e4bf1774-0fbc-40d6-93c5-e4d674c05de5&p=1|dead-url= yes|archive-date= 18 January 2013|newspaper= Edmonton Journal|date= 15 December 2008|accessdate= 7 November 2012}} The university predicted a $59-million budget shortfall in 2009{{cite web|last=Taves|first=Jonathan|title=2010/11 tuition, fees could rise with $59-million gap|url=http://ottewell.gateway.ualberta.ca/articles/news/2009/10/15/201011-tuition-fees-could-rise-59-million-gap|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120721082829/http://ottewell.gateway.ualberta.ca/articles/news/2009/10/15/201011-tuition-fees-could-rise-59-million-gap|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 July 2012|work=The Gateway|publisher=Gateway Student Journalism Society|accessdate=10 March 2012}} before provincial cuts brought that figure to $79 million.{{cite news |title= U of A reels from $20M surprise cut; Staff layoffs likely as university copes with existing $59M deficit, provost says|first= Elise|last= Stolte|url= |newspaper= Edmonton Journal|date= 15 December 2008|accessdate= |page= A1}} To close the budgetary gap, the university increased non-instructional fees by $290 per year{{cite news|title=U of A students tapped an extra $290|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/story/2010/03/26/edmonton-university-alberta-student-fee.html|publisher=CBC News Edmonton|accessdate=15 March 2013}} laid off teaching and support staff, and even eliminated phones in some departments (such as English and Film Studies).{{cite web|last=Dunning|first=Hayley|title=Budget deficit, Mathewson, hazing rituals top campus news stories for 2010|url=http://ottewell.gateway.ualberta.ca/articles/news/2011/01/11/budget-deficit-mathewson-hazing-rituals-top-campus-news-stories-2010|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120719094931/http://ottewell.gateway.ualberta.ca/articles/news/2011/01/11/budget-deficit-mathewson-hazing-rituals-top-campus-news-stories-2010|dead-url=yes|archive-date=19 July 2012|work=The Gateway|publisher=Gateway Student Journalism Society|accessdate=10 March 2010}} The 2013 Alberta Budget cut provincial post-secondary grants by $147 million, including a 7.2 per cent cut to the university's base operating grant. The university is covering its resulting shortfall by reducing total spending in 2013 by $28 million, then cutting an additional $56 million to balance its budget by the spring of 2015.{{cite web|last=Bennett|first=Dean|title=University Of Alberta Eyes Budget Cuts In Wake Of Reduced Funding|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2013/03/13/university-of-alberta-budget-cuts_n_2868425.html|work=Metro News|publisher=The Canadian Press|date=13 March 2013|accessdate=10 April 2013}}{{cite news|title=The University of Alberta plans to cut another $56 million from its budget|url=http://www.edmontonjournal.com/University+Alberta+plans+another+million+from+budget/8826107/story.html|accessdate=7 October 2013|newspaper=Edmonton Journal|date=23 August 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022062956/http://www.edmontonjournal.com/University+Alberta+plans+another+million+from+budget/8826107/story.html|archive-date=October 22, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The 2015 Alberta Budget released in October 2015 restored a 1.4 per cent cut to the U of A's operational funding, and provided for an additional two per cent increase in the 2015-16 fiscal year. The budget also included a two-year tuition freeze.{{cite web|title=Budget Highlights|url=http://alberta.ca/budget/highlights.cfm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151215041953/http://alberta.ca/budget/highlights.cfm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=15 December 2015|publisher=Government of Alberta|accessdate=2 November 2015}} October also saw the launch of an institutional strategic planning process intended to prompt discussion and gather feedback on the university's strategic priorities, with the goal of assuming a national leadership role in post-secondary education.{{cite web|title=Institutional Strategic Plan|url=https://uofa.ualberta.ca/strategic-plan|website=UAlberta.ca|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=2 November 2015}} ==Academics== [[File:Humanities-Centre-University-of-Alberta-Edmonton-Alberta-Canada-01A.jpg|thumb|left|The Humanities Centre]] [[File:UalbertaArtsBldg.jpg|thumb|left|Arts Building]] The U of A has about 39,300 students, including 7,700 graduate students and 7,800 international students representing 151 countries. The university has 3,620 academic staff along with 15,380 support and trust staff. University professors have won more [[3M]] Teaching Fellowships (Canada's top award for undergraduate teaching excellence) than any other Canadian university, 41 awards since 1986.{{cite web|year=2014|url=http://uofa.ualberta.ca/why-ualberta/ualbertafacts/teaching|title=University of Alberta Facts: Teaching Excellence|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=September 4, 2014}} The university offers [[post-secondary]] education in about 200 undergraduate and 170 [[Graduate school|graduate]] programs. Tuition and fees for both fall and winter semesters are slightly more than $5,000 for a typical undergraduate arts student, although they vary widely by program. The University of Alberta switched from a 9-point grading scale to the more common 4-point [[GPA in Canada|grading scale]] in September 2003. Sixty-eight Rhodes Scholars have come from the University of Alberta. ===Faculties and colleges=== {{See also|Faculties and departments of the University of Alberta}} [[File:Mechanical Engineering Building University Of Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 01A.jpg|thumb|left|The Mechanical Engineering Building]] [[File:Natural Resources Engineering Facility University Of Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 03A.jpg|thumb|upright|The Natural Resources Engineering Facility]] [[File:Earth Sciences Building University of Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 01.jpg|thumb|left|The Earth Sciences building]] [[File:Saint Josephs College University Of Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 06A.jpg|thumb|left|The chapel of St. Joseph's College]] The university has eighteen [[Faculty (division)|faculties]]: * '''Faculty of Agricultural, Life and Environmental Sciences''' focuses on [[Natural resource|natural]], biological, and [[human resources]].{{cite web|title= Faculty of Agricultural, Life & Environmental Sciences|url= http://www.ales.ualberta.ca/FacultyResearch.aspx|publisher= University of Alberta|accessdate= July 27, 2012|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120628012527/http://www.ales.ualberta.ca/FacultyResearch.aspx|archive-date= June 28, 2012|dead-url= yes|df= mdy-all}} The faculty is home to the Devonian Botanic Garden in [[Devon, Alberta]]. The garden runs a series of winter hardiness trials on trees, shrubs, herbs, annuals and bulbs. The garden collection consists of Primula, Meconopsis, Allium Rosa (shrub), alpines, and herbs and plants traditionally used by Aboriginal Peoples. There is a microfungus collection and a herbarium that contains more than 4,800 livery genotypic filamentous fungi.{{cite web|url=http://www.museevirtuel-virtualmuseum.ca/GetMuseumProfile.do?lang=en&chinCode=guaacy|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130628051349/http://www.museevirtuel-virtualmuseum.ca/GetMuseumProfile.do?lang=en&chinCode=guaacy|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-06-28|title=Virtual Museum of Canada: Devonian Botanic Garden}} * '''[[University of Alberta School of Business|Alberta School of Business]]''' offers [[MBA]], [[BCom]], PhD, [[Executive Education|ExecEd]], [[Executive MBA|Exec MBA]], and Master of Financial Management degrees. * '''[[University of Alberta Faculty of Arts|Faculty of Arts]]''' is home to a spectrum of arts programs and departments, from [[Anthropology]] and Community Service Learning to History and [[Women's Studies]]. * '''[[University of Alberta Augustana Faculty|Augustana Campus]]''' is located in a satellite campus in [[Camrose, Alberta]]. It comprises the departments of Fine Arts, Humanities, Physical Education, Science, and Social Sciences. * '''[[University of Alberta Faculté Saint-Jean|Campus Saint-Jean]]''' is a francophone faculty with programs in Sciences, Fine Arts and Languages, Social Sciences, and Education. * '''Faculty of Education''' offers undergraduate and graduate degrees in elementary and secondary education, or a combined program. The [[School of Library and Information Studies at the University of Alberta|School of Library and Information Studies]] is also a part of this Faculty. * '''[[University of Alberta Faculty of Engineering|Faculty of Engineering]]''' offers undergraduate degrees in five engineering departments. Students can choose to specialize in the following disciplines: [[Chemical Engineering]], [[Civil Engineering]], [[Computer Engineering]], [[Electrical Engineering]], [[Engineering Physics]], [[Materials Engineering]], [[Mechanical Engineering]], [[Mining Engineering]] and [[Petroleum Engineering]]. * '''[[University of Alberta Faculty of Extension|Faculty of Extension]]''' offers more than 300 courses in over 30 programs focusing on lifelong [[Continuing Education]] and [[Professional Development]]. Among the faculty's contributions to Alberta's educational and cultural life are the creation of the [[CKUA]] public radio station in 1927 and the Banff School of Fine Arts in 1933. * '''Faculty of Graduate Studies and Research''' maintains more than 170 programs in [[graduate studies]]. * '''[[University of Alberta Faculty of Law|Faculty of Law]]''' is the oldest law school in Western Canada.{{cite web|title=Creation of the Faculty of Law|url=http://lawschool.ualberta.ca/about/history.aspx|publisher=Faculty of Law, University of Alberta|accessdate=30 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130614205716/http://lawschool.ualberta.ca/about/history.aspx|archive-date=June 14, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} It is home to interdisciplinary institutes of constitutional studies, health law, science policy and law reform in Alberta.{{cite web|title=Faculty of Law - Centres and Institutes|url=http://lawschool.ualberta.ca/centres.aspx|publisher=Faculty of Law, University of Alberta|accessdate=30 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023034606/http://lawschool.ualberta.ca/centres.aspx|archive-date=October 23, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} * '''[[University of Alberta Faculty of Medicine and Dentistry|Faculty of Medicine & Dentistry]]''' has 20 departments, seven divisions, eight research groups, and 31 centres and institutes. The faculty is internationally known for research in diabetes, obesity, virology, cardiology, cancer and spinal injury rehabilitation.{{cite web|title=100 Years of Medicine - Dean's Message|url=http://www.med100uofa.ca/Message%20from%20the%20Dean.aspx|publisher=Faculty of Medicine & Dentistry, University of Alberta|accessdate=26 October 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223184748/http://www.med100uofa.ca/Message%20from%20the%20Dean.aspx|archive-date=February 23, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} * '''Faculty of Native Studies''' is Canada's only stand-alone faculty of native studies. The faculty began offering a master's program in the 2012-13 academic year.{{cite web|title= Grad students take new step in native studies|url= http://www.news.ualberta.ca/article.aspx?id=69410E2371E44BC9B04EF973A9D7285C|publisher= University of Alberta|accessdate= October 23, 2012|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20121009183538/http://www.news.ualberta.ca/article.aspx?id=69410E2371E44BC9B04EF973A9D7285C|archive-date= October 9, 2012|dead-url= yes|df= mdy-all}} * '''Faculty of Nursing''' is one of Canada's largest nursing faculties, and was the first in Canada to offer a fully funded PhD program.{{cite web|title=About the Faculty of Nursing|url=http://www.nursing.ualberta.ca/en/About.aspx|publisher=Faculty of Nursing, University of Alberta|accessdate=30 October 2012}} * '''[[University of Alberta Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences|Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences]]''' is one of Canada's largest and finest pharmacy faculties. Its students excel nationally, achieving the highest combined score on the Pharmacy Examining Board of Canada exam in 2009, 2010 and 2012.{{cite web|title=About Pharmacy|url=http://www.pharm.ualberta.ca/About_the_Faculty/About_Pharmacy.aspx|publisher=Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Alberta|accessdate=22 August 2013}} * '''Faculty of Kinesiology, Sport, and Recreation''' focuses on the studies of human movement through sport science, [[kinesiology]], physical education, physical activity and health, and tourism studies.{{cite web |title= Faculty of Physical Education and Recreation|url= http://www.physedandrec.ualberta.ca/|publisher= University of Alberta|accessdate=October 24, 2012}} The Faculty of Kinesiology, Sport, and Recreation offers four undergraduate programs: Bachelor of Arts in Recreation, Sport and Tourism; Bachelor of Physical Education; Bachelor of Physical Education/Bachelor of Education (five-year combined degree offered in conjunction with the Faculty of Education); and Bachelor of Science in Kinesiology.{{cite web|title= Faculty of Physical Education and Recreation: Undergraduate Programs|url= http://www.physedandrec.ualberta.ca/UndergraduatePrograms.aspx|publisher= University of Alberta|accessdate= October 24, 2012|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20121012202707/http://www.physedandrec.ualberta.ca/UndergraduatePrograms.aspx|archive-date= October 12, 2012|dead-url= yes|df= mdy-all}} * '''Faculty of Rehabilitation Medicine''' is North America's only stand-alone faculty dedicated to rehabilitation science, physical therapy, occupational therapy and speech-language pathology. The faculty is a research leader in musculoskeletal health, spinal cord injuries, seniors' health, and use of communication technologies to support local community care.{{cite web|title=Rehabilitation at the U of A|url=http://www.rehabilitation.ualberta.ca/en/RehabilitationattheUofA.aspx|publisher=Faculty of Rehabilitation Medicine, University of Alberta|accessdate=2 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120923151152/http://www.rehabilitation.ualberta.ca/en/RehabilitationattheUofA.aspx|archive-date=September 23, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} * '''School of Public Health''' was established in March 2006 as Canada's first stand-alone faculty with a sole focus on public health.{{cite web|title=About Us - School of Public Health|url=http://www.publichealth.ualberta.ca/en/about_us.aspx|publisher=School of Public Health, University of Alberta|accessdate=2 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015070538/http://www.publichealth.ualberta.ca/en/about_us.aspx|archive-date=October 15, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} In October 2012, it became the only school in Canada and only the second outside the United States to be accredited by the U.S. Council on Education for Public Health.{{cite web|last=Lauder|first=Andrea|title=UAlberta School of Public Health first accredited in Canada|url=http://www.news.ualberta.ca/article.aspx?id=18458C1065CD42CB932F68860D302903|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=9 November 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121113181102/http://www.news.ualberta.ca/article.aspx?id=18458C1065CD42CB932F68860D302903|archive-date=November 13, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} * '''Faculty of Science''' is made up of seven departments (Biological Sciences, Chemistry, Computing Science, Earth and Atmospheric Sciences, Mathematical and Statistical Sciences, Physics, and Psychology.) The faculty includes 6 Steacie Award winners, 16 winners of Rutherford Awards for Excellence in Undergraduate Teaching, 26 Canada Research Chairs, 5 iCORE Chairs, 3 NSERC Chairs, 2 Alberta Ingenuity Centres of Excellence, and 10 members of the Royal Society of Canada. It has more than 70 bachelor of science (BSc) programs in 39 subject areas.{{cite web|title=University of Alberta Faculty of Science|url=http://www.science.ualberta.ca/|work=University Homepage|accessdate=October 23, 2012}} The university has two affiliated colleges: * '''[[St. Joseph's College, Edmonton|St. Joseph's College]]''' offers undergraduate courses in applied ethics, philosophy, religious education and theology, for credit in degree programs with arts options. The college also offers specific courses for education students intending to teach within Alberta's Catholic school system.{{cite web|title=About Us - St. Joseph's College|url=http://www.stjosephs.ualberta.ca/en/About.aspx|publisher=St. Joseph's College, University of Alberta|accessdate=2 November 2012}} * '''St. Stephen's College''' offers graduate degree, diploma and certificate programs in theological studies, with courses designed to allow distance learning.{{cite web|title=About the College|url=https://www.ualberta.ca/ST.STEPHENS/about/mission_and_values.htm|publisher=St. Stephen's College, University of Alberta|accessdate=2 November 2012}} ===Libraries=== [[File:Rutherford Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 02.jpg|thumb|upright|Winspear Business Reference Library]] The University of Alberta library system received a tremendous boost with the opening of the [[Rutherford Libraries |publisher=University of Alberta Libraries |accessdate=2012-06-23}} {{as of|2012}}, according to the [[Association of Research Libraries]], the library system is rated 11th in North America and is the second-largest, by number of volumes held, among all Canadian universities, after the [[University of Toronto]] Library.{{cite
