Scott Health Sciences Library]]''' * '''[[Rutherford Library]]''' (Humanities & Social Sciences) ** Bruce Peel Special Collections Library * '''St. Joseph's College Library''' * '''Winspear Business Reference Library''' The university is home to an [[American Library Association]]-accredited '''School of Library and Information Studies,''' which offers a [[Master of Library and Information Studies]] (MLIS) program.{{cite web|year=2012|url=http://www.slis.ualberta.ca/en/AboutSLIS.aspx|title=About SLIS|publisher=School of Library and Information Studies|accessdate=October 26, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012202455/http://www.slis.ualberta.ca/en/AboutSLIS.aspx|archive-date=October 12, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The school is housed in [[Rutherford Library|Rutherford South]], the original four-storey brick, marble and oak main campus library, which opened in 1951. ==Scientific research== [[File:UofAPillar.jpg|thumb|British artist and U of A alumni Andrew French installs his 1999 sculpture, "Pillar," on the University of Alberta campus, November 2012.]] Housing over 400 distinct research laboratories, the University of Alberta is one of the leading research universities in Canada.{{cite web|title=Canada's University Innovation Leaders: Canada's Top 50 Research Universities 2012|url=http://www.researchinfosource.com/media/Top%2050%20LR-2012.pdf|publisher=Research Infosource|accessdate=27 February 2013}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The university is a member of the [[U15 (universities)|U15]] universities and the [[Worldwide Universities Network]], an organization of 19 universities on six continents. The university receives nearly $500 million each year for research from external sources.{{cite web|year=2013|url=http://www.why.ualberta.ca/ualbertafacts/sponsoredrevenue|title=University of Alberta Facts: Sponsored Research Revenue|publisher=The University of Alberta|accessdate=August 22, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130821230751/http://why.ualberta.ca/ualbertafacts/sponsoredrevenue|archive-date=August 21, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The University of Alberta is the national scientific and administrative headquarters for: * Sustainable Forest Management Network * [[Canadian Obesity Network]] * Canadian Centre for Ethnomusicology Researchers at the University of Alberta have made discoveries in a number of fields.{{cite web|title=Transformative Research|url=http://why.ualberta.ca/ualbertafacts/Research.aspx|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=9 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130201072444/http://www.why.ualberta.ca/ualbertafacts/Research.aspx|archive-date=February 1, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ===Arts and humanities research === The Faculty of Arts includes eight Canada Research Chairs in fields as diverse as English and Film Studies, Sociology, Philosophy, Art and Design, and History and Classics. In 2014 the Department of English and Film Studies ranked #22 in the World QS University Rankings by subject.{{cite web|url=http://www.efs.ualberta.ca/en/EnglishandFilmStudiesNews/2014/September/201415QSWorldUniversityRankings.aspx|title=2014-15 QS World University Rankings - English and Film Studies - University of Alberta|accessdate=July 3, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704143814/http://www.efs.ualberta.ca/en/EnglishandFilmStudiesNews/2014/September/201415QSWorldUniversityRankings.aspx|archive-date=July 4, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ===Scientific and medical research=== * In 1917, physics professor Robert Boyle developed [[sonar]]. * Biochemistry professor and alumnus James Collip played a key role in discovering insulin by refining the pancreatic extract obtained by Frederick Banting, Charles Best and John Macleod so it could be used in humans. * Chemistry professor Raymond Lemieux was the first to synthesize sucrose. The breakthrough laid the groundwork for new antibiotics and blood reagents, anti-rejection drugs for organ transplants, and better treatments for leukemia and hemophilia. * In 1956, surgeon John Callaghan performed the first successful open-heart surgery. * Canada's first organ transplant research group was established at the University of Alberta on April 2, 1970, by the Medical Research Council. * In 1995, engineer Robert Burrell used nanotechnology to develop a form of silver that could be made into a bandage for burns and other wounds. The dressings are used worldwide. * Medical researchers [[James Shapiro (physician)|James Shapiro]], Jonathan Lakey and Edmond Ryan developed the [[Edmonton Protocol]], a revolutionary treatment for [[Diabetes mellitus type 1|Type 1]] [[diabetes]] that enables people with the disease to break their [[insulin]] dependence.{{cite web|year=2000|url=http://www.med.ualberta.ca/news-publications/article.cfm?id=20|title=New treatment for diabetes major step forward in the fight against the disease|publisher=Faculty of Medicine & Dentistry, University of Alberta|access-date =December 8, 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061110003931/http://www.med.ualberta.ca/news-publications/article.cfm?id=20|archive-date=November 10, 2006}} The first patient was treated in 1999. {{as of|2006}}, the project is developed through the Clinical Islet Transplant Program. * In 2008, medical researcher David Bundle and his colleagues Glen Armstrong and Pavel Kitov made a breakthrough in treating ''E. coli'' infection by creating a drug that prevents the ''E. coli'' bacterium from making contact with kidney cells. * In 2013, [[Michael Houghton (virologist)|Michael Houghton]], Canada Excellence Research Chair and Li Ka Shing Chair in Virology, showed that a vaccine created from one strain of the hepatitis C virus can be effective against all known strains of the virus. Houghton was also the researcher who originally identified the hepatitis C virus. The discovery paves the way for developing a vaccine to prevent future hepatitis C infections. * The University of Alberta consistently ranks as the second best university in the world when it comes to [[Artificial Intelligence]] and [[Machine Learning]]. The university plays host to world class research and development in such subject areas, and in 2017, was awarded $125 Million in funding from the Government of Canada to be shared amongst four other Canadian universities for further research and advancements in the field.{{cite web|url=http://m.metronews.ca/#/article/news/edmonton/2017/04/06/university-of-alberta-gets-funds-for-artificial-intelligence.html|title=Metro News|website=m.metronews.ca}} [[File:NINT.JPG|thumb|left|The National Institute for Nanotechnology]] ===Nanotechnology research=== In June 2006, a $120-million building for the [[National Institute for Nanotechnology]] (NINT) was opened on campus. The NINT complex is one of the world's most technologically advanced research facilities, housing the quietest and cleanest laboratory space in Canada.{{cite web| year = 2006|url = http://www.nrc-cnrc.gc.ca/newsroom/news/2006/nint06-nr_e.html|title = Flagship Nanotechnology Institute's New Home Features Canada's Quietest Space| publisher = The National Research Council of Canada| accessdate =December 8, 2006| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061003074152/http://www.nrc-cnrc.gc.ca/newsroom/news/2006/nint06-nr_e.html| archivedate = October 3, 2006}} NINT occupies five floors of the new building, with the top two floors being reserved by the university for [[nanotechnology]]-related research. Some staff members have been jointly recruited by the [[National Research Council of Canada|NRC]] and the University of Alberta. ===Arctic research=== The University of Alberta is home to the Canadian Circumpolar Institute, which supports research into social and environmental issues including climate change, cultural identity and natural resource development. In 2011, researchers at the University of Alberta linked the reproductive ecology of polar bears in Canada's [[Hudson Bay]] with decreasing litter sizes and loss of [[sea ice]]. ===Agriculture=== Cattle researcher Roy Berg revolutionized the world's beef industry with his innovations in crossbreeding, which led to a 30 to 40 per cent increase in production and contributed to Alberta's world leadership in beef production. ===Energy, oilsands and environment=== In the 1920s, engineering professor Karl Clark developed a hot-water extraction process to separate bitumen from oilsands. Geology professor Charlie Stelck's idea to search for oil and gas deposits near ancient coral reefs led to the discovery of oil in Leduc, Alberta, in 1947 and in the Pembina Oil Field in 1953. Today, more than 1,000 researchers at the University of Alberta are working together on oilsands issues and their environmental effects, including carbon capture and storage, tailings-pond reclamation and water preservation. University of Alberta's SLOWPOKE-2 non-power reactor operating licence was renewed and will be valid from July 1, 2013 until June 30, 2023. The [[SLOWPOKE reactor]] is used for research and education.{{cite web|url=http://nuclearsafety.gc.ca/eng/mediacentre/releases/news_release.cfm?news_release_id=465|title=University of Alberta’s SLOWPOKE-2}} === Machine learning and artificial intelligence === The University of Alberta hosts the Alberta Machine Intelligence Institute (AMII),{{cite web|url=https://www.amii.ca/|title=Amii}} an institute dedicated to [[machine learning]] and [[artificial intelligence]], formerly known as Alberta Innovates Centre for Machine Learning (AICML). AMII is home to world-renowned computer scientists including Professors Rich Sutton ([[Reinforcement Learning]]), [[Osmar R. Zaiane]] ([[Data Mining]]), [[Russell Greiner]] ([[Health Informatics]]), Michael Bowling ([[Game Theory]]), Dale Schuurmans ([[Machine Learning]]), Csaba Szepesvari (Reinforcement Learning), Martha White (Machine Learning), among others. The computing science department at University of Alberta is ranked #1 in [[Canada]] and averaged #2 in the world in terms of number of publications at top [[Artificial Intelligence]] and [[Machine Learning]] venues in the last 10 years.{{cite web|url=http://csrankings.org/|title=csranking|website=Computer Science Rankings}} In 2017, the [[Government of Canada]] Budget included an investment of $125 million into a Pan-Canadian Artificial Intelligence Strategy,{{cite web|url=http://www.fin.gc.ca/n17/17-026-eng.asp|title=Growing Canada's Advantage in Artificial Intelligence|website=Department of Finance}} which features a major investment in research at the University of Alberta.{{cite news|url=https://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/canada-funds-125-million-pan-canadian-artificial-intelligence-strategy-616876434.html|title=Canada funds $125 million Pan-Canadian Artificial Intelligence Strategy}} ===Other=== * The university participated in the initial development of the [[Mizar system]].{{cite web|title=Mizar: The first 30 years|url=http://webdocs.cs.ualberta.ca/~piotr/Mizar/History/04MMA/M30.pdf|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=14 December 2012|author=Matuszewski, R.|author2=Rudnicki, P.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150507155134/http://webdocs.cs.ualberta.ca/~piotr/Mizar/History/04MMA/M30.pdf|archive-date=May 7, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} * The [[asteroid]] [[99906 Uofalberta]] is [[Meanings of asteroid names|named in the university's honour]], in part because the initials of its motto ''Quaecumque Vera'' ("Whatsoever things are true") appeared in the object's [[provisional designation in astronomy|provisional designation]] {{mp|2002 QV|53}}.{{cite web| year = 2002| url = http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=99906;orb=0;cov=0#discovery| title = Jet Propulsion Laboratory Small-Body Database: 99906 Uofalberta (2002 QV53)|publisher = NASA|accessdate =October 25, 2012}} ==Reputation== {{Canadian university rankings | UniName = University of Alberta | ARWU_W = 101-150 | ARWU_CAN = 5–6 | QS_W= 109 | QS_N = 4 | THES_W = 132 | THES_N = 6 | THES_GEUR = 124 | USNWR_GU = 137 | USNWR_N = 6 | MAC_med = 6 | MAC_rep = 6 }} The University of Alberta has consistently been ranked one of Canada's top universities. In the 2018 ''[[Academic Ranking of World Universities]]'' (ARWU) rankings, the university ranked 101-150 in the world and 5–6 in Canada. The 2019 ''[[Times Higher Education World University Rankings]]'' placed the University 132nd in the world, and sixth in Canada. The 2019 ''[[QS World University Rankings]]'' ranked the university 109th in the world and fourth in Canada. In ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' 2019 global university rankings, the university placed 137th, and sixth in Canada. In ''[[Maclean's]]'' 2019 rankings, the University placed 6th in both the Medical-Doctoral university category, and in their reputation ranking for Canadian universities. The University of Alberta was ranked in spite of having opted out from participation in ''Maclean's'' graduate survey since 2006.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/11-universities-bail-out-of-maclean-s-survey-1.570771|title=11 universities bail out of Maclean's survey|accessdate=17 August 2017|work=CBC News|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|date=14 April 2006}} The University of Alberta also placed in a number of rankings that evaluated the employment prospects of graduates. In the Times Higher Education's 2017 global employability ranking, the University placed 124th in the world, and sixth in Canada. In QS's 2018 graduate employability ranking, the university ranked 94th in the world, and fifth in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/employability-rankings/2018|title=Graduate Employability Ranking 2018|accessdate=18 November 2017|work=QS Top Universities|publisher=QS Quacquarelli Symonds Limited|year=2017}} Several programs from the University's have also garnered notability. In QS' 2017 ranking for the subject of education, the University ranked 49th in the world, and fourth in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/university-subject-rankings/2017/education-training|title=Education|work=QS World University Rankings|accessdate=6 December 2017|publisher=QS Quacquarelli Symonds Limited|year=2017}} In the ''Times Higher Education'''s 2018 ranking for the subject of education, the University was ranked 60th in the world, and fourth in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/2018/subject-ranking/education#!/page/0/length/25/sort_by/rank/sort_order/asc/cols/stats|title=World University Rankings 2018 by subject: education|publisher=Times Higher Education|work=Times Higher Education World University Rankings|accessdate=6 December 2017|year=2017}} The University has also ranked in a number of rankings relating to [[hospitality management]]. In the ARWU's 2017 subject ranking for hospitality management and tourism, the University placed 38th in the world, and third in Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Shanghairanking-Subject-Rankings/hospitality-tourism-management.html|title=ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects 2017 - Hospitality & Tourism Management|year=2016|accessdate=6 December 2017|publisher=ShanghaiRanking Consultancy|work=Academic Ranking of World Universities}} In QS' 2017 subject ranking for hospitality and leisure management, the University was ranked 45th in the world, and second in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/university-subject-rankings/2017/hospitality-leisure-management|title=Hospitality & Leisure Management|work=QS World University Rankings|accessdate=6 December 2017|publisher=QS Quacquarelli Symonds Limited|year=2017}} In the ARWU's 2017 subject ranking for [[agricultural science]], the University was ranked 33rd in the world, and third in Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Shanghairanking-Subject-Rankings/agricultural-sciences.html|title=ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects 2017 - Agricultural Sciences|year=2016|accessdate=6 December 2017|publisher=ShanghaiRanking Consultancy|work=Academic Ranking of World Universities}} In the 2017 ''U.S. News & World Report'' ranking for agricultural sciences, the University was ranked 68th in the world, and third in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/best-global-universities/canada/agricultural-sciences|title=Best Global Universities for Agricultural Sciences|work=U.S. News & World Report|accessdate=6 December 2017|year=2017|publisher=U.S. News & World Report LP.}} In the ARWU's 2017 subject ranking for environmental science and engineering, the University was placed 9th in the world, and first in Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Shanghairanking-Subject-Rankings/environmental-science-engineering.html|title=ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects 2017 - Environmental Science & Engineering|year=2016|accessdate=6 December 2017|publisher=ShanghaiRanking Consultancy|work=Academic Ranking of World Universities}} In the 2017 ''U.S. News & World Report'' ranking for the subject of environment and [[ecology]], the University was ranked 75th in the world, and fourth in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/best-global-universities/environment-ecology|title=Best Global Universities for Environment/Ecology|work=U.S. News & World Report|accessdate=6 December 2017|year=2017|publisher=U.S. News & World Report LP.}} In the ARWU's 2017 ranking for [[mining engineering]], the University was ranked 24th in the world, and third in Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Shanghairanking-Subject-Rankings/mining-mineral-engineering.html|title=ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects 2017 - Mining & Mineral Engineering|year=2016|accessdate=6 December 2017|publisher=ShanghaiRanking Consultancy|work=Academic Ranking of World Universities}} In QS' 2017 ranking for mining engineering, the University was ranked 18th in the world, and fifth in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/university-subject-rankings/2017/engineering-mineral-mining|title=Mineral & Mining Engineering|work=QS World University Rankings|accessdate=6 December 2017|publisher=QS Quacquarelli Symonds Limited|year=2017}} In particular, for the field of health sciences, the University of Alberta has placed in the rankings of several publications. In the ''Times Higher Education'''s 2018 rankings for the field of clinical, pre-clinical, and health, the University was ranked 77th in the world, and sixth in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/2018/subject-ranking/clinical-pre-clinical-health#!/page/0/length/25/sort_by/rank/sort_order/asc/cols/stats|title=World University Rankings 2018 by subject: clinical, pre-clinical and health|publisher=Times Higher Education|work=Times Higher Education World University Rankings|accessdate=6 December 2017|year=2017}} In the QS' 2017 rankings for subject of nursing, the University ranked 16th in the world, and second in Canada.{{cite web|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/university-subject-rankings/2017/nursing|title=Nursing|work=QS World University Rankings|accessdate=6 December 2017|publisher=QS Quacquarelli Symonds Limited|year=2017}} In the ARWU's 2017 rankings for nursing, the University was ranked 32nd in world, and second in Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Shanghairanking-Subject-Rankings/nursing.html|title=ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects 2017 - Nursing|year=2016|accessdate=6 December 2017|publisher=ShanghaiRanking Consultancy|work=Academic Ranking of World Universities}} In QS' 2017 ranking for the subject of pharmacy and [[pharmacology]], the University was ranked 44th in world, and fourth in Canada.{{cite web|url=|title=Pharmacy & Pharmacology|work=QS World University Rankings|publisher=QS Quacquarelli Symonds Limited|year=2017}} In the ARWU's ranking for pharmacology and pharmaceutical sciences, the University was ranked 98th in the world, and fourth in Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/Shanghairanking-Subject-Rankings/pharmacy-pharmaceutical-sciences.html|title=ShanghaiRanking's Global Ranking of Academic Subjects 2017 - Pharmacy & Pharmaceutical Sciences|year=2016|accessdate=6 December 2017|publisher=ShanghaiRanking Consultancy|work=Academic Ranking of World Universities}} ==Campuses== The university has five distributed campuses including, in addition to the North Campus, two auxiliary satellites: Campus Saint-Jean in southeast Edmonton, and Augustana Campus in [[Camrose, Alberta|Camrose]], 90 kilometres southeast of Edmonton. An extensively renovated and refurbished historic [[Hudson's Bay (retailer)|Hudson's Bay]] department store in downtown Edmonton, renamed Enterprise Square, serves as a campus for adult students belonging to the Faculty of Extension. The university owns a set of large parcels of mostly undeveloped land (used as an experimental farm and the site of several agricultural and sports facilities) slightly south of the main campus, called South Campus (previously the University Farm), in which an entire new university complex of similar magnitude to the North Campus will be constructed. Detailed Google Maps views and 360-degree interactive panoramas of the campus can be seen on the University of Alberta website. ===North Campus=== {{Main|List of University of Alberta buildings}} [[File:U of A.jpg|thumb|The University of Alberta overlooks the North Saskatchewan River valley and downtown Edmonton.]]The North Campus is the original location of the University of Alberta. Located on the southern banks of the [[North Saskatchewan River]], it has 150 buildings on {{convert|92|ha|acre}} of land.{{cite web|year = 2012|url = http://www.aucc.ca/canadian-universities/our-universities/university-of-alberta-3|title = The Directory of Canadian Universities: University of Alberta|publisher = AUCC|accessdate = August 31, 2012|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120923081056/http://www.aucc.ca/canadian-universities/our-universities/university-of-alberta-3|archive-date = September 23, 2012|dead-url = yes|df = mdy-all}} Architect [[Barton Myers]] completed the long-range campus plan in 1969 and continued as a planner for the University until 1978. The distinctive cupola of the Dentistry/Pharmacy Centre on North Campus was featured in a commemorative stamp issued by Canada Post in 2008, the year of the university's centenary.{{cite web|url=http://data4.collectionscanada.gc.ca/netacgi/nph-brs?s1=(University.TITP.)+Or+(University.TITI.+And+null.B742.)&l=20&d=STMP&p=1&u=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/archivianet/02011702_e.html&r=14&f=G&Sect1=STMP|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130101011441/http://data4.collectionscanada.gc.ca/netacgi/nph-brs?s1=(University.TITP.)+Or+(University.TITI.+And+null.B742.)&l=20&d=STMP&p=1&u=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/archivianet/02011702_e.html&r=14&f=G&Sect1=STMP|dead-url=yes|archive-date=January 1, 2013|title=Canadian Postal Archives Database|accessdate=July 3, 2015}} ===South Campus=== Located two kilometres south of the North Campus, the South Campus is much larger in terms of land area. The two campuses are linked by [[Edmonton Light Rail Transit|Light Rail Transit]]. The [[South Campus/Fort Edmonton Park station|LRT station]] is near '''Foote Field''' and the '''Saville Community Sports Centre''', forming a natural gateway to the new campus architectural model, since 2009. Along with [[Health Sciences/Jubilee station|Health Sciences]], [[University station (Edmonton)|University]], and [[Bay/Enterprise Square station|Enterprise Square stations]], the LRT connects the U of A through four stations. Much of the university's agricultural research in food safety and crop use for food and industrial products happens at the Edmonton Research Station Experimental Farms on South Campus. This campus is also home to the Saville Community Sports Centre, a 32,500-square-metre, multi-use recreation facility that hosts 14 varsity teams and several community sports clubs. In 2013, the Saville Centre became the new training centre for the Canadian senior women's basketball team.{{cite web|title=Edmonton home to Canada's senior women's basketball team|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/story/2013/06/27/edmonton-women-basketball-team.html|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=22 August 2013}} ===Campus Saint-Jean=== The [[University of Alberta Faculté Saint-Jean|Campus Saint-Jean]] is a [[francophone]] campus located five kilometres east of the main campus, in [[Bonnie Doon, Edmonton|Bonnie Doon]]. It is the only French-language university campus west of [[Manitoba]]. Due to increasing enrolment, the Campus Saint-Jean is undergoing expansion, acquiring new laboratory and classroom spaces. Students at Campus Saint-Jean pursue bachelor's degrees in the sciences or arts, or complete their first year of Engineering, after which they often transfer to the University of Alberta's main campus. Bilingual Nursing and Business programs are also available. ===Augustana Campus=== The [[University of Alberta Augustana Faculty|Augustana Campus]] is located in [[Camrose, Alberta|Camrose]], a small city in rural Alberta about 100 km southeast of Edmonton. In 2004, the former [[Augustana University College]] in Camrose merged with the University of Alberta, thus creating the new satellite Augustana Campus. Students enrolled at the Augustana Campus currently pursue four-year bachelor's degrees in arts, sciences, or music. ===Enterprise Square=== Enterprise Square opened for business January 15, 2008 on the north side of the [[North Saskatchewan]] river in downtown [[Edmonton]].{{cite web|year = 2008|url=http://www.enterprisesquare.ualberta.ca/~/media/enterprisesquare/Documents/LaunchMediaRelease15Jan2008.pdf|title = University of Alberta officially opens Enterprise Square downtown campus|publisher = University of Alberta|accessdate =October 25, 2012}} It is located in the historical building previously occupied by the [[Hudson's Bay Company]]. The building underwent major renovations. Enterprise Square houses the [[University of Alberta Faculty of Extension]], the professional development activities of the [[University of Alberta School of Business|Alberta School of Business]], the Alberta Business Family Institute, and the Design Gallery. It is the home of the University of Alberta Alumni Association. ==Investment in health and science== $1.6 billion in construction has been undertaken at the university related to fields in health and science. The projects expand the University of Alberta's research capacity in the field of health. Over the past five years, the University of Alberta has averaged nearly $500 million in external research funding a year.{{cite web |url=http://why.ualberta.ca/ualbertafacts/sponsoredrevenue |title=UAlberta Facts: Sponsored Research Revenue |publisher=ualberta.ca |accessdate=2013-08-22 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130821230751/http://why.ualberta.ca/ualbertafacts/sponsoredrevenue |archive-date=August 21, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} The funding is expected to increase due to added research and teaching capacity. ===Centennial Centre for Interdisciplinary Science=== A major project, completed in the spring of 2011 with a grand opening on September 23, 2011, was the $400-million, Centennial Centre for Interdisciplinary Science (CCIS),{{cite web|year = 2006|url = http://top100projects.ca/2009/centennial-centre-for-interdisciplinary-sciences-phase-2/|title = Top 100 Projects|publisher = Renew Canada|accessdate = December 22, 2009|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100411073447/http://top100projects.ca/2009/centennial-centre-for-interdisciplinary-sciences-phase-2/|archive-date = April 11, 2010|dead-url = yes|df = mdy-all}} a facility for interdisciplinary research groups, as well as the Department of Physics, the Faculty of Science offices and the Interdepartmental Science Students' Society's office. Three buildings – V-Wing (a large one-floor building composed of 10 lecture halls, of which two will remain), the Avadh Bhatia Physics Building (a six-storey building formerly housing the Department of Physics offices and laboratories), and the old Centre for Subatomic Research{{cite web|year = 2006|url = http://www.science.ualberta.ca/CIS_updates.cfm|title = CCIS – Construction Updates|publisher = University of Alberta Faculty of Science|accessdate = December 27, 2006|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20061209151347/http://www.science.ualberta.ca/CIS_updates.cfm|archive-date = December 9, 2006|dead-url = yes|df = mdy-all}} – were demolished to make way for CCIS. ===Edmonton Clinic Health Academy=== The Edmonton Clinic (formerly the Health Science Ambulatory Learning Centre) is a joint project with Alberta Health Services, and consists of two separate buildings. Construction started in 2008 on the multidisciplinary health science facilities totalling $909 million and 170,000 square metres surrounding the [[Health Sciences/Jubilee LRT Station|Health Sciences LRT Station]]. Edmonton Clinic South (now known as [[Edmonton Clinic|Kaye Edmonton Clinic]]), a nine-storey building, will focus on patient care and house most of the medical and dental clinics, while the Edmonton Clinic Health Academy (ECHA) is a six-storey building that is the home of interdisciplinary health research and education currently held at the university. The Edmonton Clinic Health Academy, owned and operated by the University of Alberta, officially opened in January 2012. The [[Edmonton Clinic|Kaye Edmonton Clinic]], owned and operated by Alberta Health Services, opened in December 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.edmontonclinic.ca/ |title=Edmonton Clinic website |publisher=Edmontonclinic.ca |accessdate=2012-06-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090822225400/http://www.edmontonclinic.ca/ |archive-date=August 22, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} ===Health research innovation facilities=== [[File:Centre for Pharmacy and Health Research University Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 01A.jpg|thumb|left|Katz Group Centre for Pharmacy and Health Research]] Two new $300-million buildings adjacent to the Heritage Medical Research Centre building on the main campus, along with existing health-care and health research facilities and the Edmonton Clinic Health Academy, form a health precinct of two city blocks dedicated to health research, education and patient care. The newest facilities form a translational research centre designed to create an environment for "bench-to-bedside" health research by increasing interaction between researchers and clinicians focused on common medical issues. A total of 65,000 square metres (699,700 square feet) gross area constructed on two sites contribute to research by allowing the university to hire over 100 additional biomedical and health researchers. This is projected to result in a doubling of research funding by 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.cgi.ualberta.ca/hrif/index.htm|title=Health Research Innovation Facility Website|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206034540/http://www.cgi.ualberta.ca/hrif/index.htm|archivedate=February 6, 2007|df=mdy-all}} '''Katz Group Centre for Pharmacy and Health Research''' The hub of the complex is the Katz Group Centre for Pharmacy and Health Research (formerly HRIF West), an eight-storey building that provides the main entrance to the complex and becomes the critical link between Medical Sciences Building and Heritage Medical Research Centre. The Katz Group Centre is a teaching and research facility. It is home to the Li Ka Shing Institute of Virology, led by scientific director [[D. Lorne Tyrrell|Lorne Tyrrell]], MD, PhD, and includes some of the world's top virologists, including [[Michael Houghton (virologist)|Michael Houghton]], PhD, Canada Excellence Research Chair and Li Ka Shing Chair in Virology, who co-led the team that discovered the [[hepatitis C]] virus during his previous career in private industry. The facility is located on the corner of 89 Avenue and 114 Street in Edmonton, Alberta. '''Li Ka Shing Centre for Health Research Innovation''' The Li Ka Shing Centre for Health Research Innovation (formerly HRIF East) anchors the southeast corner of the health precinct and is also home to the Alberta Diabetes Institute (ADI). Both the east and west buildings of HRIF are linked at every floor to the Heritage Medical Research Centre with the exception of Level 1 of HRIF West. The facility is dedicated to health research and boasts state-of-the-art laboratories for top researchers, including several Canada Research Chairs.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.ualberta.ca/article.aspx?id=32DEAB75F6C245D7B67D182318F4F31D|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130101112635/http://www.news.ualberta.ca/article.aspx?id=32DEAB75F6C245D7B67D182318F4F31D|dead-url=yes|archive-date=January 1, 2013|title=Article - University of Alberta|accessdate=July 3, 2015}} The facility is named in honour of a gift in 2010 of $28 million from the Li Ka Shing (Canada) Foundation that helped establish the Li Ka Shing Institute of Virology ($25M) and a joint PhD program ($3M) between the university's Faculty of Medicine & Dentistry and Shantou University Medical College in China.{{cite web|url=https://www.ualberta.ca/SIGNATURE/LiKaShingCentre.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130115150209/http://www.ualberta.ca/SIGNATURE/LiKaShingCentre.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-01-15|title=The power of partnership: Li Ka Shing Foundation gift and Government of Alberta funding to establish virology institute at University of Alberta}} As of fall 2012, this remains the largest single cash gift to the University of Alberta. The facility is located on the corner of 89 Avenue and 112 Street in Edmonton, Alberta. ==Student life== [[File:Students Union Building University Of Alberta Edmonton Alberta Canada 01A.jpg|thumb|The Students' Union Building hosts a number of student organizations, including the [[University of Alberta Students' Union]].]] The student body of the University of Alberta is represented by two [[students' unions]], the [[University of Alberta Students' Union]] for all undergraduate students, and the Graduate Student Association for all graduate students.{{cite web|url=http://www.su.ualberta.ca/about/whoweare/|title=Who We Are - University of Alberta Student Union|publisher=University of Alberta Students' Union|accessdate=20 January 2014|year=2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gsa.ualberta.ca/en/01AboutTheGSA.aspx|title=About the GSA - Graduate Students' Association|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=20 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201173127/http://www.gsa.ualberta.ca/en/01AboutTheGSA.aspx|archive-date=February 1, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} In addition, a number of the university's academic programs also manage their own student representative body. Students within the residences are represented by a number of associations, primarily the University of Alberta Residence Halls Association.{{cite web|url=http://www.residence.ualberta.ca/en/CurrentResidents/ResidenceStaff/ResidenceAssociations.aspx|title=Residence Associations|accessdate=20 January 2014|publisher=University of Alberta|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201173127/http://www.residence.ualberta.ca/en/CurrentResidents/ResidenceStaff/ResidenceAssociations.aspx|archive-date=February 1, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} There are more than 450 student organizations and clubs, covering a wide range of interests such as academics, culture, religion, social issues, and recreation.{{cite web|url=http://www.su.ualberta.ca/services/studentgroups/|title=Student Group Services|publisher=University of Alberta Students' Union|year=2014|accessdate=20 January 2014}} The student unions', as well as many of the student organizations, are centred in the university's [[student activity centre]], the Students' Union Building. The building was opened in 1967, and hosts the majority of the Students' Union services and business operations.{{cite web|url=http://www.gradstudies.ualberta.ca/en/facultystaff/council.aspx|title=Students' Union Building (SUB)|publisher=University of Alberta Students' Union|year=2014|accessdate=20 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201173128/http://www.gradstudies.ualberta.ca/en/facultystaff/council.aspx|archive-date=February 1, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The two primary media outlets amongst the student population is the [[student newspaper]], [[The Gateway (newspaper)|The Gateway]], and [[campus radio]], [[CJSR-FM]].{{cite web|url=http://thegatewayonline.ca/static/view/about|title=About - The Gateway|publisher=Gateway Student Journalism Society|accessdate=20 January 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://cjsrfm88.blogspot.ca/p/contact-us.html|title=CJSR 88|accessdate=20 January 2014}} ===Greek life=== From 1909 to 1929, the university held a ban against fraternities and sororities, since [[Henry Marshall Tory]], the first president of the university, ordered all secret societies, including Upsilon Upsilon and Pi Sigma Phi, to be disbanded.{{sfn|Schoeck|2006|p=214}} The drive to remove the ban begun in 1927, when students had formed the Athenian Club to lobby the university. During the same year, several men had formed the Rocky Mountain Goat Club, which was only official sanctioned due to the lack of any secret rituals or a written constitution.{{sfn|Schoeck|2006|p=214}} The ban on fraternities and sororities would end in 1929, with the departure of President Tory. Members of the Rocky Mountain Goat Club had later formed the nucleus of the university's first fraternities.{{sfn|Schoeck|2006|p=214}} [[Phi Delta Theta]] was the first fraternity officially recognized and chartered on September 2, 1930.{{cite web|url=http://www.deanofstudents.ualberta.ca/FraternityandSororityLife.aspx|title=Fraternity and Sorority Life|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=20 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140210021304/http://www.deanofstudents.ualberta.ca/FraternityandSororityLife.aspx|archive-date=February 10, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Fraternities and sororities are recognized as student groups by the University and Students' Union through Student Group Services. They are supported by local alumni advisors, their international headquarters, and a fraternity and sorority advisor. In addition, the fraternities are also governed by the [[Interfraternity Council]] and the [[Panhellenic Council]]. There are eleven fraternity chapters recognized as a student group by the university, and the Students' Union, [[Delta Chi]], [[Delta Kappa Epsilon]], [[Delta Upsilon]], [[FarmHouse]], [[Kappa Sigma]], [[Lambda Chi Alpha]], Phi Delta Theta, [[Phi Gamma Delta]], [[Pi Kappa Alpha]], [[Theta Chi]], and [[Zeta Psi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.deanofstudents.ualberta.ca/en/FraternityandSororityLife/Fraternities.aspx|title=U of A Fraternities|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=20 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140130130838/http://www.deanofstudents.ualberta.ca/en/FraternityandSororityLife/Fraternities.aspx|archive-date=January 30, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} There are currently six sorority chapters recognized as a student group by the university, and the Students' Union, [[Alpha Gamma Delta]], Alpha Psi, Ceres, [[Delta Gamma]], [[Kappa Alpha Theta]], and [[Pi Beta Phi]].{{cite web|url=http://www.deanofstudents.ualberta.ca/FraternityandSororityLife/Sororities.aspx|title=U of A Sororities|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=20 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140130224426/http://www.deanofstudents.ualberta.ca/FraternityandSororityLife/Sororities.aspx|archive-date=January 30, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ===Athletics=== {{main|University of Alberta Golden Bears}} The Athletics program at the university is managed by the Athletics Department, a service unit under the Faculty of Kinesiology, Sport, and Recreation. The university's male varsity teams are known as the [[University of Alberta Golden Bears]], while the female varsity team is known as the [[Alberta Pandas|University of Alberta Pandas]]. The university's varsity teams compete in the [[Canada West Universities Athletic Association]] conference of [[U Sports]]. The university's varsity sports programs include basketball, cross-country, curling, football, golf, hockey, rugby, soccer, swimming, track and field, tennis, volleyball, and wrestling. The university athletic's department manages more than 500 students in over 24 teams.{{cite web|url=http://athletics.ualberta.ca/connect/about-us|title=About Us - Golden Bear and Panda athletics|year=2014|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=20 January 2014}} [[File:Bears-vs-Huskies.jpg|thumb|left|The [[Alberta Golden Bears|Golden Bears]] football team playing [[Canadian football|football]] against the [[University of Saskatchewan Huskies]]. Football is one of 13 varsity programs offered by the University's athletics program.]] The Golden Bears and Pandas have won 68 national championships since 1961.{{cite web|title=University of Alberta: Sports|url=http://uofa.ualberta.ca/why-ualberta/ualbertafacts/sports|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=4 September 2014}} The men's ice hockey team has won the Canada West Conference Championships championship 25 times, and the national championship 15 times, making it the Golden Bears' most successful team at the regional and national level.{{cite web|url=http://athletics.ualberta.ca/connect/athletics-history/championship-tradition/cis-national-championships|title=CIS National Championships|publisher=University of Alberta|year=2014|accessdate=25 February 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209160453/http://www.athletics.ualberta.ca/connect/athletics-history/championship-tradition/cis-national-championships|archive-date=February 9, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://athletics.ualberta.ca/connect/athletics-history/championship-tradition/canada-west-conference-championships|title=Canada West Conference Championships|publisher=University of Alberta|year=2014|accessdate=25 February 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140209161911/http://www.athletics.ualberta.ca/connect/athletics-history/championship-tradition/canada-west-conference-championships|archive-date=February 9, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The Faculty of Kinesiology, Sport, and Recreation also operate a number of intramural, sport club and group fitness programs, available to any undergraduate and graduate student that pays the Athletic and Recreation fee through the Campus & Community Recreation service unit. Sports offered include traditional sports like volleyball, basketball, soccer and cricket, as well as less traditional events like dodgeball, inner tube water polo, and [[wallyball]].{{cite web|url=http://recservices.ualberta.ca/en/Programs/RecSports.aspx|title=Intramural/Recreational Sports|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=25 February 2014|year=2014}} The university has athletic facilities open to both their varsity teams as well as to their students. Opened in 2015, the Physical Activity and Wellness (PAW) Centre opened as a partnership between the Students' Union, Graduate Students Association, the Faculty of Kinesiology, Sport, and Recreation, University of Alberta, the Government of Alberta and the Hanson and Wilson Family. The PAW Centre encourages healthy lifestyles choices by offering a variety of activities related to wellness. Components include a new student fitness centre, sports-related research and lab facilities, a variety of student service spaces as well as the new home of the Steadward Centre, a high-caliber research and program delivery centre for people with disabilities. Foote Field is a multi-sport facility named after its benefactor, Eldon Foote. The sports facility is home to the varsity Golden Bears and Pandas track and field, football, soccer and rugby.{{cite web|url=http://www.physedandrec.ualberta.ca/Facilities/FooteField.aspx|title=Foote Field|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=20 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203171341/http://www.physedandrec.ualberta.ca/Facilities/FooteField.aspx|archive-date=December 3, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Depending on the sporting event, the field's seating capacity ranges from 1,500-3,500.{{cite web|url=http://www.physedandrec.ualberta.ca/Facilities/FooteField/Amenities.aspx|title=Amenities|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=20 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203172711/http://www.physedandrec.ualberta.ca/Facilities/FooteField/Amenities.aspx|archive-date=December 3, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Foote Field also hosts the Canadian Athletics Coaching Centre, and had previously hosted events in international athletics competitions, such as the [[2001 World Championships in Athletics]]. Other facilities include the Van Vliet Complex, named after [[Maury Van Vliet]], the first director of the Faculty of Physical Education (Nowthe Faculty of Kinesiology, Sport, and Recreation). The facility holds physical activity spaces including; the Clare Drake Arena several gymnasium, an aquatic centre, fitness centres, and courts for racquetball and squash.{{cite web|url=http://athletics.ualberta.ca/connect/about-us/facilities|title=Facilities|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=20 January 2014}} The Saville Community Sports Centre is another multi-sport complex located on the university's campus. The centre is also home of the Golden Bears and Pandas basketball, curling, tennis and volleyball teams, and houses the Canadian Curling Association National Training Centre, Tennis Canada High Performance Tennis Development Centre, and Team Ortona Gymnastics. The university also operates the Universiade Pavilion, a multi-sport facility constructed for the [[1983 Summer Universiade]]. ==Insignias and other representations== ===Coat of arms=== The university coat of arms was adopted in 1909, following the recommendations of the university's senate to adopt the coat of arms of the province of Alberta as its emblem, with the addition of an open book superimposed upon the cross and a new motto. The coat of arms had undergone a number of changes, with the arms changing in the 1950s in keeping with the graphic style of the time, and in the early-1990s, in the university's efforts to have their arms gain official heraldic authority.{{cite web|url=http://www.toolkit.ualberta.ca/VisualIdentityGuidelines/CoatOfArms.aspx|title=Coat of Arms|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=19 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201172713/http://www.toolkit.ualberta.ca/VisualIdentityGuidelines/CoatOfArms.aspx|archive-date=February 1, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The latest design was completed in 1994, being registered with the [[Canadian Heraldic Authority]] on 31 May 1994, and was presented to the university on 13 June 1994.{{cite web|url=http://reg.gg.ca/heraldry/pub-reg/project.asp?lang=e&ProjectID=1747&ShowAll=1|title=University of Alberta|publisher=Governor General of Canada|accessdate=19 January 2014}} The coat of arms consists of a shield displaying the topography of Alberta rendered in the colours of the University. At the base is a prairie wheat field symbolizing Alberta's agricultural industry.{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.ualberta.ca/en/UofATraditionsandHallmarks/UniversityCoatofArms.aspx|title=University Coat of Arms|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=19 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201172616/http://www.senate.ualberta.ca/en/UofATraditionsandHallmarks/UniversityCoatofArms.aspx|archive-date=February 1, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The wavy gold line above represent the hills and rivers of Alberta. The top of the shield is in gold and separated from the rest of the shield by a line suggesting the Rocky Mountains. The book of learning dominates the design. A [[great horned owl]], the provincial bird and an accepted symbol of knowledge is used as the crest of the coat of arms. The arm's supporters is the [[pronghorn]], taken from the provincial coat of arms, and the golden bear, the mascot of the university. ===Motto and song=== The motto of the university, ''Quaecumque vera'', translates to "whatsoever things are true." The original motto ''lux et lex'', was first adopted in 1907, and was translated as "light and law" in Latin. The motto was substituted with the present motto in 1909. The motto was adopted from the Latin [[Vulgate]] version of the Bible, the [[Epistle to the Philippians]], where it states that,{{cite web|url=http://www.toolkit.ualberta.ca/WhatIsOurPromise/OurVisionMissionMotto.aspx|title=Our Vision, Mission & Motto|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=19 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201172715/http://www.toolkit.ualberta.ca/WhatIsOurPromise/OurVisionMissionMotto.aspx|archive-date=February 1, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} {{quotation | Epistle to the Philippians, Chapter 4, Verse 8: — :Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue and there be any praise, think on these things.}} Notable among a number of songs commonly played and sung at events such as [[graduation|commencement]] and [[convocation]], and athletic games are: ''Alberta'', with words and music by Emma Newton; ''Alberta Cheer Song'', with words by R.K. Michael, and music by Charleston Lamberston; ''The Evergreen and Gold'', with words by William H. Alexander, and the music taken from the [[National Anthem of Russia]]; and ''Quaecumque vera'', with words and music by Ewart W. Stutchbury.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/college-songs-and-songbooks-emc/|title=College Songs and Songbooks|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|publisher=Historica Foundation|date=12 July 2013|last=Green|first=Rebecca|accessdate=19 January 2014}} ===Symbols=== The official colours of the university are green and gold. The green represents the wide stretches of prairie land flanked by deep spruce forests and is symbolic of hope and optimism; the gold represents the golden harvest fields and is symbolic of the light of knowledge. The original suggestion for green and gold colours came from Marion Kirby Alexander, drawing inspiration from the autumn colours of the river valley below the campus.{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.ualberta.ca/UofATraditionsandHallmarks/UniversityColours.aspx|title=University Colours|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=19 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201172709/http://www.senate.ualberta.ca/UofATraditionsandHallmarks/UniversityColours.aspx|archive-date=February 1, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Her husband, William Hardy Alexander, a professor at the university, relayed the suggestion to a faculty meeting on 5 October 1908 and would later gain the approval of the senate. The university colours are present throughout the institution. These colours are also displayed on the university flag. The university flag consists of the shield of the coat of arms on a gold background.{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.ualberta.ca/UofATraditionsandHallmarks/UniversityFlag.aspx|title=University Flag|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=19 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201172614/http://www.senate.ualberta.ca/UofATraditionsandHallmarks/UniversityFlag.aspx|archive-date=February 1, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ==Notable people== {{Main|List of University of Alberta people}} {{See also|List of Presidents of the University of Alberta|List of Chancellors of the University of Alberta}} File:JoeClark.jpg|[[Joe Clark]], [[List of Prime Ministers of Canada|16th]] [[Prime Minister of Canada]]. File:Beverley McLachlin (crop).jpg|[[Beverley McLachlin]], 17th [[Chief Justice of Canada]]. File:Prof Michael Houghton.jpg|[[Michael Houghton (virologist)|Michael Houghton]], virologist and co-discoverer of [[hepatitis c]]. File:RayLemieux.jpg|[[Raymond Lemieux]], [[organic chemist]] and discoverer of the [[anomeric effect]]. File:Richard E. Taylor.jpg|[[Richard E. Taylor|Richard Taylor]], [[Nobel Prize|Nobel laureate]] in [[Nobel Prize in Physics|physics]] for his contributions in [[particle physics]]. File:Derek Walcott.jpg|[[Derek Walcott]], Nobel laureate in [[Nobel Prize in Literature|literature]] for his work with [[Postcolonial literature|postcolonial poetry]] File:Margaret Atwood 2015.jpg|[[Margaret Atwood]], poet, novelist, essayist and literary critic. File:Clarence Campbell Stanley Cup 1957.jpg|[[Clarence Campbell]], 3rd [[NHL Commissioner|President of the National Hockey League]]. The University of Alberta has 260,000 living graduates, 93 per cent of whom reside in Canada. Outside of Canada, the United States holds the greatest amount of alumni, nearly four per cent of all living graduates.{{cite web|url=http://www.newtrail.ualberta.ca/winter2013/features/where-you-live|title=Where You Live & What You Do|last=Andrews|first=Marcy|publisher=University of Alberta|date=5 December 2013|accessdate=19 January 2014}} Alumni and former students have won awards, including 68 [[Rhodes scholar|Rhodes Scholarships]].{{cite web|url=http://uofa.ualberta.ca/why-ualberta/ualbertafacts/students|title=University of Alberta Student Numbers|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=17 November 2014}} Distinguished alumni include [[Raymond Lemieux]], awarded the [[Albert Einstein World Award of Science]] in 1992,{{cite web|url=http://www.consejoculturalmundial.org/winners-science-raymondulemieux.php|title=Prof. Raymond U . Lemieux|publisher=World Cultural Council|accessdate=19 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140220165802/http://www.consejoculturalmundial.org/winners-science-raymondulemieux.php|archivedate=February 20, 2014|df=mdy-all}} and former faculty member [[Malcolm Forsyth]], three-time award winner of the [[Juno Award for Classical Composition of the Year|Juno Award for Classical Composition]]{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/composer-malcolm-forsyth-dies-at-74-1.1109680|title=Composer Malcolm Forsyth dies at 74|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=19 January 2014|date=5 July 2011}} In the literary arts there are writers Aritha Van Herk, Caterina Edwards, and Joseph Pivato. The university is also associated with two Nobel laureates, alumni [[Richard E. Taylor]], who was awarded the [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] in 1990,{{cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1990/taylor-bio.html|title=Richard E. Taylor - Biographical|publisher=Nobel Media AB|date=14 January 2014|accessdate=19 January 2014}} and faculty member [[Derek Walcott]], who was awarded the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] in 1992.{{cite web|url=https://www.ualberta.ca/english-film-studies/efsnews/2017/march/derek-walcott|title=Nobel laureate Derek Walcott passed away at the age of 87|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=3 November 2018|date=17 March 2009}} A number of graduates have achievements in business, including [[Daryl Katz]], chair of the [[Katz Group of Companies]] and owner of the [[Edmonton Oilers]],{{cite web|url=http://www.edmontonjournal.com/business/darylkatzedmontonreclusivebillionaire/interactive/index.html|title=Daryl Katz: Edmonton's reclusive billionaire|publisher=Postmedia Network Inc.|work=Edmonton Journal|last1=McConnell|first1=Rick|last2=MacKinnon|first2=John|last3=Lamphier|first3=Gary|year=2014}} [[Bernard Ebbers]], former CEO of [[MCI Inc.|WorldCom]],{{cite book|title=Telecoms in the Internet Age: From Boom to Bust To--?|first=Martin|last=Fransman|page=195|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2002|isbn=0-1992-5700-0}} and [[Greg Zeschuk]], and [[Ray Muzyka]], co-founders of [[BioWare]].{{cite web|url=http://www.edmontonsun.com/2012/09/19/ray-muzyka-and-greg-zeschuk-announce--they-are-departing--edmonton-video-game-development-firm|title=Ray Muzyka and Greg Zeschuk announce they are departing Edmonton video game development firm.|accessdate=19 January 2014|date=18 September 2012|last=Dykstra|first=Matt|work=The Edmonton Sun|publisher=Canoe Sun Media}} In academia, a number of faculty members and graduates also gained prominence including faculty member [[Ludwig von Bertalanffy]], for his work [[general systems theory|systems theory]],{{cite book|title=Beyond Art: A Third Culture: A Comparative Study in Cultures, Art and Science in 20th Century Austria and Hungary|year=2005|first=Peter|last=Weibel|publisher=Springer|isbn=3-2112-4562-6|page=376}} and alumni [[Tak Wah Mak]], discoverer of the [[T-cell receptor]].{{cite web|url=http://cdnmedhall.org/dr-tak-wah-mak|title=Dr. Tak Wah Mak|publisher=Canadian Medical Hall of Fame|year=2014|accessdate=19 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828160146/http://www.cdnmedhall.org/dr-tak-wah-mak|archive-date=August 28, 2010|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Many former students have gained local and national prominence for serving in government. Alumnus [[Roland Michener]] served as the 20th [[Governor General of Canada]].{{cite book|title=Canada's Prime Ministers, Governors General and Fathers of Confederation|publisher=Pembroke Publishers Limited|year=2005|isbn=1-5513-8185-0|first=Irma|last=Coucill|page=92}} The 16th [[Prime Minister of Canada]], [[Joe Clark]], also graduated from Alberta.{{cite book|title=Mavericks|first=Aritha Van|last=Herk|isbn=0-1431-7695-1|publisher=Penguin Canada|year=2010}} A number of graduates have served at the provincial level, as [[Premier (Canada)|premiers]] and [[lieutenant governor (Canada)|lieutenant governors]], including [[George Stanley]], the 25th [[Lieutenant Governor of New Brunswick]] and designer of the [[flag of Canada|Canadian flag]].{{cite web|url=http://people.stfx.ca/lstanley/stanley/stanley.htm|title=Col. the Hon. George F.G. Stanley (1907-2002)|publisher=St. Francis Xavier University|last=Stanley-Blackwell|first=Laurie|accessdate=19 January 2014|year=2007}} [[Lois Hole]], the former chancellor of the university, served as the 15th [[Lieutenant Governor of Alberta]].{{cite book|title=Lois Hole Speaks: Words that Matter|publisher=Wayne State University Press|year=2008|last=Hole|first=Lois|isbn=0-8886-4488-4|page=3}} Graduates who served as provincial premiers include [[Pat Binns]], the 30th [[Premier of Prince Edward Island]],{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.pe.ca/premiersgallery/patbinns.php3|title=Pat Binns|publisher=Government of Prince Edward Island|accessdate=19 January 2014}} [[Peter Lougheed]], the 10th [[Premier of Alberta]],{{cite book|title=Alberta Premiers of the Twentieth Century|publisher=University of Regina Press|year=2004|first=Bradford James|last=Rennie|page=205|isbn=0-8897-7151-0}} Dave Hancock, the 15th Premier of Alberta, [[Jim Prentice]], the 16th Premier of Alberta,{{cite web|title=Premier of Alberta|url=http://alberta.ca/premier.cfm|website=Government of Alberta|publisher=Government of Alberta|accessdate=17 September 2014}} and [[Rachel Notley]], the 17th Premier of Alberta.{{cite web|title=What you need to know about Rachel Notley star|url=http://www.macleans.ca/news/canada/what-you-need-to-know-about-rachel-notley/|work=The Canadian Press|publisher=[[Macleans]]|date=May 5, 2015|accessdate=June 26, 2015}} [[Ed Stelmach]], the 13th Premier of Alberta, attended the university but did not finish.{{cite web|url=https://www.assembly.ab.ca/lao/library/premiers/Stelmach.htm|title=The Honourable Edward M. Stelmach, 2006-2011|publisher=Legislative Assembly of Alberta|accessdate=19 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714182322/https://www.assembly.ab.ca/lao/library/premiers/Stelmach.htm|archive-date=July 14, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The third chancellor of the university, [[Alexander Cameron Rutherford]], also served as the first premier of Alberta.{{cite book|title=I Was There: A Century of Alumni Stories about the University of Alberta, 1906–2006|publisher=University of Alberta Press|year=2006|last=Schoeck|first=Ellen|isbn=0-8886-4464-7|page=342}} A number of graduates also held office in the [[Parliament of Canada]], including [[Rona Ambrose]], who served as the [[President of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada]],{{cite web|url=http://www.foa.ualberta.ca/Alumni/Alumni%20Profiles/The%20Honourable%20Rona%20Ambrose.aspx|title=The Honourable Rona Ambrose|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=19 January 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201172613/http://www.foa.ualberta.ca/Alumni/Alumni%20Profiles/The%20Honourable%20Rona%20Ambrose.aspx|archive-date=February 1, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} and [[David Emerson]], who served as the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Canada)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]].{{cite web|url=http://www.finning.com/Governance/Biography/default.aspx?ItemId=b5633a0c-f8b9-4d46-b343-cf597fb0cfab|title=HON. DAVID L. EMERSON PC, OBC|publisher=Finning International Inc.|year=2011|accessdate=19 January 2014}} The 17th [[Chief Justice of Canada]], [[Beverley McLachlin]], the first female chief justice, is a graduate from the university.{{cite book|title=The Supreme Court of Canada and its Justices 1875-2000|page=72|isbn=1-7707-0095-1|publisher=Dundurn|year=2000}} Other faculty and alumni who have served on Canada's highest court include Justice Henry Grattan Nolan, who served for a year before dying in 1957; Justice Ronald Martland, who served on the court for 24 years beginning in 1958; Justice Gérard Vincent La Forest, a former dean of law at the U of A who was elevated to the court in 1985 and served for 12 years; former law professor and alumnus Justice William Stevenson, who served two years on the court beginning in 1990; and former law professor Justice Russell Brown, who was named to the court in 2015.{{cite web|title=Former UAlberta law professor named to the Supreme Court of Canada|url=https://uofa.ualberta.ca/news-and-events/newsarticles/2015/july/former-ualberta-law-professor-named-to-the-supreme-court-of-canada|website=www.ualberta.ca|publisher=University of Alberta|accessdate=17 August 2015}} [[Violet King Henry]] was the first black woman lawyer in Canada, the first black person to graduate law in Alberta and the first black person to be admitted to the Alberta Bar. She was also the first woman named to a senior management position with the American national YMCA. ==See also== {{portal|Alberta|Edmonton|University|University of the Arctic}} * [[Canadian government scientific research organizations]] * [[Canadian industrial research and development organizations]] * [[Canadian university scientific research organizations]] * [[Folkways Records]] * [[Higher education in Alberta]] * [[List of agricultural universities and colleges]] * [[List of universities in Canada]] * [[University of Alberta Protective Services]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== {{refbegin}} * William Hardy Alexander, ''The University of Alberta: A Retrospect 1908–1929''.
